Goal

Comprehensive Planning and Coordi-
nation: The legislation establishing the
Council provides for methods of solv-
ing the region’s probiems which in-

land for industry is good transportation
to outside markets by highway, rail,
water, and air. Accessibility by public
and private transportation, water and
sewer facilities, and proximity to the

labor force are other essential require-

ards to increase the compatibility of
industrial areas with surrounding devel-
opment.

The central core or MetroCenter should
be extended and redeveloped. Thi

should be supplemented by a system of

[N

It is desirable to work toward a system
of regional public financial programming
to implement elements of the General
Development Plan. This will require
cooperative organization of lpocal, state
and federal financial resources. The

rendering planning assistance, pro-
viding advisory review and referral
and other services to assist implemen-
tation. In all these activities, the
Council strives to work with its mem-
ber governments to cut the red tape
which often slows or blocks action,
and to work efficiently and effectively
toward solving the problems of the
region.

Increased assistance from state and
federal governments is required to meet
local responsibilities, to relieve the

ernmental agencies, and voluntary ShA R R A L EL o level of activity, landscaping, and the require ciose cooraina LAURCl
/ 2

organizations.

It is estimated that in the next 20 years,
100,000 additional acres, or about 7
percent of the region, will be required

for new development.

Residential land area requirements to
meet projected growth are in the vicinity
of an additional 64,000 acres of land,

of which 49,000 acres will be in single-
family development and 15,000 acres in
multi-family development. Over 85 per-
cent of new residential land will be
developed in Anne Arundel, Baltimore
and Howard Counties.

There are now about 13,000 acres used
as commercial land, and about 9,000
additional acres will be needed by 19290

Of prime consideration in proposing

tives: integration of development with
natural physiographic characteristics;
proximity to major activity centers; vari-
ety in location so that residential devel-
opment can take place in varying
degrees of density.



Local jurisdictions should seek to im-
prove commercial deveiopment by re-
ducing the size of buildings in relation

to total site acreage and increasing
landscape requirements, thereby achiev-
ing compatibility with the surrounding
neighborhood.

Efforts should be made by local jurisdic-
tions to improve industrial developments
by requiring more effective methods of
discharging liquid and solid wastes;
attacking the sources of water and air
pollution; upgrading landscape stand-

mixture of land uses most appropriate

to each.

Implementation Process

A continuing process should be devel-
oped for implementation of the regional
General Development Plan.

The Regional Planning Council can
serve an important role in this process,
working with agents of local, state and
national governments, with private enter-
prise and the citizens of the region.

A regional economic development
advisory committee can prove helpful to
the efforts of organizations to enhance
socio-economic development of the
region.

developers.

Attention needs to be focused on the
regional economy, its characteristics,
and its effects on employment, incomes,
consumer needs and the ability of local
governments to service their populations.
The Regional Planning Council should
continue to develop a broader communi-
cation process for citizens' participation
in implementation of the General Devel-
opment Plan, working with the local
jurisdictions, technical committees,
public and private agencies, citizens’
committees, organizations and associ-
ations.

Community information and education
programs should be expanded, using

all available methods.
